title: Australian Prime Minister officially declares that football is called football.

author: 1relaxingstorm
text: When I call it football, someone comments that it's soccer. When I comment "soccer", someone comments that it's "football". Makes me wonder if these people even like the game at all...

author: ShitPostQuokkaRome
text: If you browsed less American heavy subs it's is usually settled as football and that's it. Usually this debate only restarts during WCs

author: 1relaxingstorm
text: Actually I noticed this happen to me on YouTube. But I can understand what u mean with that context

author: Liljendal
text:
The vast majority of the world call it one way, which is in the name used in FIFA. Sure, 2 sports evolved from the same sport simply referred to as Football, but one of these has a much better association to the name than the other, especially if you compare to Handball and Basketball.

Therefore, this shouldn't be a debate. There is only one true name for this sport, and it's high time people accepted it. Then again, some countries drive on the left, while others refuse the Metric system, so there will always be rebels trying to point out otherwise, but they are quite simply wrong.

author: marktwainbrain
text:
"Vast majority" -- what does that have to do with it? Minority languages are okay, why do you want to wash them away? Chinese people say 足球 (zuqiu) for soccer/football, so what? I live in a word big enough for bangers and sausages, lifts and elevators, lorries and trucks. I'm sorry your world isn't big enough for linguistic diversity within the English-speaking world.

"There is only one true name for this sport" ... you sound like a religious zealot. Unassailable fact: there is more than one name for this sport. The term "soccer" is much less common in most places, but very common in other places. "It's high time people accepted it."

This is not nearly as big a deal as the metric system. It would actually be better (to avoid errors, for one reason) for non-metric countries to gradually shift. But "football" vs "soccer" is just one of countless examples of variations in vocabulary that truly do not matter at all.

author: Liljendal
text:
I never said anything about washing away minority languages? My own native language is spoken by less than a million people, and we also call it "football" (translated of course, "fótbolti/knattspyrna" latter being literally "sphere-kick" so almost the same).

What's up with the attacks based on pure assumptions anyway? I do realize I come off as quite the zealot, but the officiating body of this sport is called FIFA, Fédération Internationale de Football Association *in French* or International Federation of Association Football *in English.* As someone mentioned, even American teams have the suffix "F.C." which stands for "Football Club".

author: marktwainbrain
text:
Your logic for why everyone should accept "football" instead of "soccer" is the same logic people use against minority languages. Your entire little screed seems to ignore the obvious fact that \*we can have two words for something.\*

The two words will continue to be used, and it will be okay. Americans will continue to talk about going to see Charlotte **FC** play **soccer**, and nothing bad will happen, I promise.

author: Liljendal
text:
Still don't understand what minority languages has anything to do with this. Neither English nor the US is in any minority as a language, and I actually fully support languages that are spoken by few, as I said I belong to such a group myself.

Our difference of opinion stems from the fact that I think there needs to be an established lingua franca term for the sport on the internet, and other international places. It's to avoid confusion. My point was that most of the world calls the sport as football in their own language, as you can see here.

If Americans in the US want to call it soccer when seeing Charlotte FC, that's fine. But trying to establish it as a lingua franca for the rest of the world isn't, as they are in a minority there, hence my majority/minority argument.

I know I'm defending this hill way too much, but to me it's a matter of avoiding confusion. If I started calling the sport *assoc*, wouldn't it be unnecessarily confusing? Yet, it's an established word for the sport, and according to your argument, that would be perfectly fine. I personally think it would complicate things.

author: cassius_claymore
text:
British people called it soccer for a long time, including when the game was brought to America. Americans also began playing a modified version and called it "football" (gridiron). Then 60 years ago the British decided to stop calling it soccer.

Now they get annoyed at Americans calling it soccer, not football. Seems fair.

author: Liljendal
text:
Could you validate that? I'm certain the official name has always been Football. I realize that soccer derives from slang for *association* as in "association football".

Besides, this isn't just about what the Brits call the sport, but other languages besides English, as [this image](https://external-preview.redd.it/iUt7eCe1S1YvCSQ5RRJH7kPcABPwz6A92RGsjV0hNeQ.jpg?auto=webp&s=dd71831a056db88866ba4ec27f2921c91f1e36ac) shows.

author: cassius_claymore
text:
The two terms were used interchangeably in Britain (and other places) for a long time. And no one had a problem with Americans calling it soccer until very recently, when the British stopped using the term ([oh wait, they still use it occasionally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer_Saturday)). By that time, the US already had another game that they had dubbed "football", so they kept calling it soccer.

What's to be done at this point? Everyone in the world knows what soccer means, but some arbitrarily decided that it's no longer a valid term.

author: Liljendal
text:
My point is that there needs to be an established term for the sport that avoids confusion. Your claim that everyone in the world knows soccer is wrong. Football is much more assiciated with the sport than soccer.

On the flipside, what's the problem for Americans to call it football when speaking with an international body, like the internet? You may find it strange to suffest that, but it's just as strange to suggest soccer as an infernational term.

author: Linumite
text:
>term for the sport that avoids confusion

But calling it soccer avoids all confusion? You just justified its use

author: Liljendal
text:
That's a naive viewpoint IMO. It's not an established term for the world, especially to non native English speakers. I realize we're all speaking in English here, but in an international community. Why not call American Football handegg to avoid confusion? Surely everyone knows what it refers to, at least everyone on this sub.

And yes, I know it's ridiculous to suggest American Football should be called handegg everywhere, but it's equally ridiculous to suggest that soccer is the international term for football.

author: Linumite
text:
Can you be more condescending please?

Everyone knows what you're referring to if you say soccer. I'd love to see one instance of someone being confused what "soccer" is

author: Liljendal
text:
>Everyone knows what you're referring to if you say soccer.

They don't. Perhaps most, but not nearly everyone. You can't simply state that as a fact. People that aren't familiar with Northern American customs (or other places that use soccer) won't know what you're talking about.

author: cassius_claymore
text:
Why did the British use the term soccer for so long? Did that cause mass confusion too? Also I'd love to meet someone on the internet who doesn't know what I mean when I say soccer.

As far as calling it football when speaking in an international context... The prevalence of American football is growing very rapidly in Europe. There are millions of fans and counting.

It's unfortunate that the two words/sports have collided like this, but changing what we call either sport would be a source of confusion for one side or another. As it stands now, calling it soccer is only a slight annoyance and avoids any confusion.

author: Liljendal
text:
I can't speak for the British, and frankly I don't think it matters if they used to sometimes call it soccer or not. It's irrelevant. I would argue that calling it football is only a slight annoyance to the few people (in an international capacity) that would confuse it with American Football.

The world cup is estimated to have 227 million people tune in **every day**, which is more people than watch the super bowl. Even if American Football is growing, it's still miles off from the viewership of Association Football, and the people that are used to refer to it as football. Therefore, I doubt many people outside the US and Canada are confused by the term.

author: DrewsThoughts
text: Your are picking the strangest hill to die on. Who the fuck cares if you call it soccer or football.

author: Liljendal
text:
Haha, I just said this in another comment:

> I know I'm defending this hill way too much

You're right, it's strange and trivial. But it matters to me, so I'll die on this hill if I have to :)

*I unfortunately seem to be dragging this into a nonsensical argument, which believe it or not was not the plan despite my sarcastic tone (which looking back seems more aggressive than sarcastic tbh)*
